Yeah, I would agree with your assessment that Duke is very focused on the pragmatic- from engineering and math to finance or politics, it[.] all about developing your skills in your chosen field, and ultimately, going on to success in that field.

But, I don't think that means we can't be humanistic as well. Some of my courses in English have, and I don't believe I'm exaggerating, changed the way I look at the world and my place in it. There[.] a lot of room for insightful discussion, and I've had more than a few conversations stretch into 3-4 am on topics ranging from utopia, free will, equality, imagination, computer science, music, sports, and so much more. It[.] just such a rewarding intellectual community to be a part of.

However, that could be said on almost any school, I think. These kinds of discourse happen at Columbia and at Harvard and Yale and Stanford and Arizona State and Southern Illinois. I don't really believe that any one school represents the perfect fit with any person- you can find a home anywhere you look.

So I suppose my response to your conjecture is that you're right, but you're also not. Duke is focused on the pragmatic. But every school is focused on the pragmatic. Duke is a wonderful place for the humanities. But most schools are wonderful places for the humanities.
